Raising interest rates too quickly could squash the nascent recovery. My own judgment is that wages have been flat over five years as a result of slack labor market conditions. If demand for workers is-- finally!-- increasing, thus increasing wages, that is a cause for celebration.

Krugman is correct that wage levels should be observed carefully before making a decision to increase interest rates. One month of data des not constitute a trend. And cutting off the recovery too soon is, in my judgment, a worse policy outcome than allowing modest inflation in the context of economic expansion.

JP:

Productivity has grown by more than 80 percent since 1973. The problem is that between 1979 and 2007, most of the income gains (60 percent) have gone to the top 1 percent, the top 0.1 percent has received an even greater share (36 percent), and only 8.6 percent of the gains have gone to the bottom 90 percent. Whereas from 1948 to 1973, workers’ wages kept up with increases in productivity. As a result, the gap between the top 1 percent and the rest of America is the widest it’s been since the 1920s.

It's absolutely facile to compare Garry's lack of upkeep with his editing with the digital process of today. The two are entirely different, and are basically incomparable except for the emulation of the chemical process the digital one attempts to superficially mimic. Digital pictures made of everything one interacts with on a given day are a desire for the individual voice. Photographs of objects or spaces in a daily routine are not made with nearly the same purpose, and are left unedited for an entirely different set of reasons, not the least of which is the obscurity of those images in a intangible nothingness.

As Marshall McLuhan said in "Understanding Media", "The world itself becomes a sort of museum of objects that have been encountered before in some other medium. It is well known that even museum curators often prefer colored pictures to the originals of various objects in their own cases. In the same way, the tourist who arrives at the Leaning Tower of Pisa, or the Grand Canyon of Arizona, can now merely check his reactions to something with which he has been long familiar, and take his own pictures of the same".

Do not mistake an unedited digital catalog of objects to have any catalyst similar to that of Garry's body of work. Garry's work was about photography, and that is interesting enough.

There is indeed something to ponder when simple neighborhood social events balloon into overgrown, commercial travesties of popular happenings. I remember the simple joys of watching the annual Halloween parade of children and adults in costumes as they wended their way up W. 10th Street to 6th Avenue where a giant spider entertained us all as it cavorted around the tower of what is now a library.  The parade moved to 6th avenue where it became a partially X-rated adult extravaganza where children where seldom to be seen (and definitely not wanted.) I found other things to do on those once "memorable evenings" but I have kept my memories of the happy children for whom this parade was originally intended to please. There is indeed a truth in the old saying, "there can be too much of a good thing".

This article is about recognizing mortality.

It occurred to me when I was about 63. The new thought was not about the indefinite future, but the defined future. Quite suddenly there was a defined future.

How to plan for it is hard. If I could know when I will die, I could do much better planning.

In the meantime, I have signed an advance directive for healthcare decisions, a will, have arranged bank and investment accounts so that my sons will have a minimum of grief to manage. I still have to get rid of things.

I find it quite liberating. I am not afraid or angry at 66. There were a lot of things I wanted to see and do when I was young. Other things happened, and I am grateful for them, not resentful that my young ambitions were not completely fulfilled. I didn't know when I was young what would give me fulfillment as life unfolded.

I am grateful for the surprises, and hope to have a few more of them.

In a call center environment, the way to handle rising wages is to provide merit raises between 2 and 3 %, then cut hours back, saying the demands of business don't require the 40 hour work week and employees must be flexible. Additionally, the metrics are set in such a way that productivity goals are unreachable even in the best conditions. Management pat themselves on the back because they saved the company millions, then run to the bank with their bonuses while the front line workers are sweating out how to pay the heating bill because they just took an unexpected 13% pay cut. Quit? Where would they go? Where would be it better? The worker is terrified because there may not be a job on the other side. There are no real options.

The worker is trapped in a job where there is no upward mobility from that environment. The wages just don't stagnate, they are actually falling, and the workers are caught in the middle.

It looks great on corporate paper, but the reality isn't nearly as bright. The buying power of those employees drops significantly. The front line, middle class, non-managerial worker that should be the backbone of American economy is, instead, digging deeper into the rut.

The pundits who talk about austerity are not talking about austerity in _their_ world; they are talking about binding it onto the backs of the middle and lower classes.

Workers on the world, untie!

@ Jean Nicolazzo, nice straw man you've built! But I see why you did it--because your argument otherwise makes no sense. I didn't say we need to get rid of gov't entirely. I'm not an anarchist. There are functions we cannot do without.

It is a fundamental blindness of Liberalism--to only see the world through a "corporate lens"--incapable of realizing the Corporate America they rail against, is the smallest part of our economy. Small and mid-sized firms hire more people, and conduct more commerce by far.

Liberals always assume infinite resources are available for higher wages in all businesses. They cannot see past the Fortune 500, CEO pay and record corporate profits. But resources are always limited--especially in small and mid-sized firms that Liberals pretend don't exist.

One of the most disheartening aspects of ownership is signing a payroll check for $1,000--and then seeing take-home of $700.00. Even more so is to discover it cost employers over $ 1,200.00--because of all contributions to gov't programs. . And most discouraging--is when employees deserves more--but don't get it because resources are eaten up by a ravenous gov't.

It's easy to be a Liberal. You get to pretend to be informed whilst sitting in the darkest ignorance--while pontificating about things you could not begin to understand. Liberals should be invited to start a business--or run one for a year. Only then will it become obvious what parts of the equation you are truly missing.

You note that the second big problem with wages is that "the wages we do earn are siphoned off to pay for big government."

You neglect to mention the VAST amount of productivity gains being siphoned off for mammoth CEO salaries and mammoth profits not shared with the workers--often offshored to avoid taxes, and, when taxes are paid at the top, subject to relatively low tax rates.

At least for our taxes, we get to live in a civilized country--assuming the tax money is spent on education, health care, infrastructure, appropriate regulation, appropriate public safety, etc. rather than on the military.

For the fruits of our labors being siphoned off to profits for the 0.01%, we get bought-and-paid-for public policy that attempts to further bleed the society dry--lack of regulation resulting in greater danger/ damage to actual people, environmental degradation, massive direct and indirect government subsidies to big business, complaints about "takers" at the bottom.

There are two problems with wages in this country; the fact that they have stagnated due to a poor economy---and the fact that the wages we do earn are siphoned off to pay for big government. But it's even worse than that. There are a whole host of hidden taxes and programs that employers pay (on behalf of their employees) that are never seen--and employees are only vaguely aware of. These consist of the Medicaid match, Social security match, state unemployment, federal unemployment, property taxes and workers' compensation. These taxes also serve to reduce employee pay--because in every business I know, resources are finite--and monies that go toward paying taxes, can't go into employees paychecks.

It's ironic; we can do 3 things to fix this issue of "not enough pay": pay people more, let workers them keep more of what they make by reducing the tax burden--or we can do both. Liberals like Krugman ONLY want to do one of these things. It's always up to business to pay more--it's never up to government to take less.

I think you miss one key point: The Democrats stopped marketing themselves to white men a generation ago. Listen to any speech on social welfare programs (which often help white men) and you will hear something like the beneficiaries are "women, the poor, and minorities." Where are the programs for men? They may exist, but they certainly aren't marketed as such. Apply for a job and they see "women and minorities are encouraged to apply." And so on. In a generation when white working class men's wages are stagnating, they are understandably looking to blame someone, and the Democrats, by marketing themselves as champions of everyone but white men, have painted a target on their backs.

Consider: If the Democratic party managed to attract as many white male voters as white female voters, the House would be in Democratic hands right now. And, given the economic policies of the Democrats and the GOP, there is no excuse for Democrats to lose the votes of ANY working class voters.

Does this mean that we need to give up on a society that includes everyone? No. It means that when we talk about policies to help the disadvantaged, whether it's affirmative action, minimum wage requirements, overtime rules, etc., we need to talk about how these programs benefit white working class men too (and of course, we need to make sure that they do actually benefit). Because they vote.

Life would be boring without suffering. We would not learn anything without suffering. We need the "not have" to know what it means to "have" something. This duality is a gift, because outside this human-earthly realm, everything is light and everyone is in bliss. supposedly.

Suffering can cripple and create strength and compassion. Sometimes, it is necessary to walk through suffering and transcend it in order to reach one's full potential, as Nelson Mandela did so magnificently.

Human beings can be at their best when they face suffering courageously, whether they attempt to minimize or eliminate it (as in the Jewish concept of tikkun olam, repairing the world), or whether they attempt to transcend it (as embodied in the Christian concept of resurrection).

"The theologian Paul Tillich has a great essay in “Shaking the Foundations” in which he observes that during moments of suffering, people discover they are not what they appeared to be. The suffering scours away a floor inside themselves, exposing a deeper level, and then that floor gets scoured away and another deeper level is revealed. Finally, people get down to the core wounds and the core loves.'

This is what Pope Francis is trying to foster in all of us, in the wake of the Great Recession, and in his comments on what led up to it.

It is ironic that Mr. Brooks brings this up amid his trademark hodge-podge, running parallel to some of the vilest, most insulting, ill-informed comments from today's fundamentalist right wing on the topics of women, sexuality, race, poverty, and that damned phrase, the dignity of work. It is very ironic that it is the right wing that is attempting to bring out the exact opposite reactions and sentiments of those I quote above, while trying to cast the opposite side as shallow and devoid of values.

Anthropology, as a whole, provides plenty of depth and understanding of nature and nurture. Philosophy is rich with meaning and content for any mind and soul open to critical thinking, empathy, and purpose.

As many of Mr. Brooks' pieces, the claim is lofty but the actions on the ground and in the airwaves are the mirror opposite.

Originally, DebbieR, T.A.V.R. was only approved for people ineligible for surgery. Now, it's offered to both those whose aortic stenosis is deemed inoperable AND to those considered "high risk." So many patients will have a choice.

They may still be sicker than those who have the traditional valve replacement surgery. But what's interesting is that the complication rate on several measures, including stroke, is higher for T.A.V.R., not lower.

Still, one problem in trying to assess which is the better option for a given patient is that there are few head-to-head studies yet.

If the T.A.V.R. patients were mostly ineligible for surgery, doesn't that mean they were sicker to begin with?  Or older? If so, how can you compare the complication rates for those patients with complication rates for those receiving surgery? How does that make sense?
